h i g h l i g h t s
SANS technique is applied to study pore structure of Longmaxi shale. Scattering intensity follows a power-law relation with an exponent D < 3, indicative of mass fractal nature. Surface area, pore size distribution and porosity calculated using PDSP and Porod models are compared to MIP method. Porosity variation is mainly related to the content of TOC and mineral composition.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 1 November 2016 Received in revised form 21 December 2016 Accepted 1 February 2017
Keywords: Longmaxi shale Small-angle neutron scattering Scattering length density Nanopore Pore structure
a b s t r a c t
Longmaxi Formation is the leading target play of shale gas development in Sichuan Basin (China) with a large amount of natural gas produced from this organic-rich overmature shale since 2014. In order to investigate the nano-scale pore system, small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) technique was applied on four Longmaxi shale samples (JY-01 to -04) with a range of different lithology. The scattering length density (SLD) for each sample is calculated as a volume average using the chemical composition of different mineral components, with values from 3.58 10 10 cm 2 in JY-02 to 3.81 10 10 cm 2 in JY-04. Scattering results and analyses reveal Longmaxi shales are mass fractal with an exponent D less than 3. Pore size distribution, specific surface area and porosity are calculated using Porod invariant method and Polydisperse spherical pore (PDSP) model, and are comparable to mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) results, suggesting SANS is valuable to study nano-scale pore space from microscopic to nearly micrometer scale. In addition, with the increasing depth and the scattering vector (Q) values, the scattering intensity decrease over five orders of magnitude, reflecting the differences in the certain scale structure of scatters at various burial depths of Longmaxi shale. For a certain Q value, with an increasing depth, the scattering intensity values initially increase slowly first, and then increase rapidly. The fractions of closed pore also increase with depth and reach the maximum in JY-04, which is related to the TOC content and mineral composition and is partially developed during the development of very complicated pore network.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The increase of energy demand and advances of drillingcompletion technologies (i.e., horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing) have promoted the widespread exploration and increased production of natural gases from shale reservoirs [1]. It is reported that the production of shale gas in United States has markedly increased from about 0.39 tcf (110.43 108 m3) in 2000 to 9.96 tcf (28.20 1010 m3, about 36.8% of total dry gas production in U.S.) in 2015 [1]. Likewise, in order to reduce the
reliance on energy imports and develop relatively clean fossil fuel, Chinese government has shown an increasing interest in shale gas resource, embarking on an ambitious shale gas development program. The technically recoverable shale gas resource in China is estimated to be around 25 1012 m3 (or 886.4 tcf), which is even greater than that of U.S. (24.4 1012 m3 or 861.7 tcf [2]).
As a new and abundant energy resource, shale gas is mainly stored in shale reservoir as free gas in pores and fractures, and adsorbed gas on the surface of organic matter and inorganic composition, as well as a small amount of dissolved gas in ‘‘in-situ” formation water, oil and bitumen [3]. Due to various gas occurrence in shale formation, its producibility is strongly related to the pore spaces and their connectivity for storing and releasing gas, which indicates the importance of pore structure study for sustainable shale resource development [4–6]. Decades-long experience of shale gas exploration and development in U.S. also suggests that gas storage, release, and flow (adsorption, desorption and diffusion) are controlled by the nano-scale pore system, such as the specific surface area and the geometry pore space (total pore volume and pore size distribution) [7–11].
Compared with conventional hydrocarbon reservoir, shale is much more complex and is often regarded to be a heterogeneous porous medium, with its composition and structure varying in multiple scales [12–14]. Pores are mainly within nanometers scale in fine-grained shale, while in tens to hundreds of microns for sandstone and carbonate reservoirs [12,15]. Therefore, conventional techniques are often not applicable to study these tiny pores and it is a challenging task for characterizing nano-scale pore system in shale reservoir.
Since the first application of Ar-ion milling and field-emission SEM imaging [15], the predominant presence of nano-scale pores in shale reservoir has been well recognized and considerable progress has been made in adapting different approaches to characterize the nano-scale pore system. Similar direct imaging methods, such as CT-scan, broad-ion-beam polishing in combination with SEM, transmission electron microscopy, helium ion microscopy, are widely used to characterize nano-scale pores, with down to nanometer resolution for some methods [5,16–19]. In addition, some indirect methods, such as mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) [11,20–23], low pressure carbon dioxide (CO2) or nitrogen (N2) adsorption [4,20,22,24], spontaneous imbibition [25], smallangle and ultra-small-angle neutron scattering (SANS/USANS) [22,26–29], helium porosimetry [4,5,30] and nuclear magnetic resonance [31,32], are also widely reported in the literature to obtain the quantitative information about pore structure of shale reservoir.
Lower Silurian marine Longmaxi shale is widely distributed in Sichuan Basin and its geologic characteristics (such as organic matter richness, shale thickness, gas content, brittleness, burial depth) are similar to, or better than, the typical producing shale reservoirs in North America [3,33–37]. In particular, high commercial natural gas was produced within this unit from the Fuling area in Southeast Sichuan Basin, which is currently the largest producing shale gas field in China. Using horizontal drilling and multi-stage hydraulic fracturing technologies, the cumulative gas production from a total of about 200 wells in the Fuling area have exceeded about 15.95 108 m3 (or 56.33 bcf) in April of 2015.
Because shale matrix is the major component in shale-gas reservoirs, great effects to characterize the pore space in Longmaxi shale has been reported over past several years. Based on high resolution SEM imaging, low pressure gas adsorption and MIP, some researchers studied the nano-scale pore system of Longmaxi shale reservoir and discovered that a significant portion of total matrix porosity is distributed in nano-scale pores, which are associated with organic matter [5,20,38–40]. Due to the complexity of shale pores and the limitation of technologies, previous investigations on pore system of gas-producing Longmaxi shale matrix are still
inadequate and these findings are mainly focused on the connected pore spaces, ignoring the closed pores to some extent.
SANS method has recently been applied to investigate the pore space of porous media, e.g., coal, sulfide ore minerals, metamorphic rocks and shale [22,28,41–45]. Combined with USANS method, some also investigate the fraction of pores in shale formation that are accessible to deuterated methane and water over a wider pore size range from 10 nm to several lm [26]. The scattering occurs at the surface between pore space and shale matrix, and information about basic structural characteristics, such as pore size distribution, porosity and fractal dimension, can be obtained from the scattering intensity. Compared with gas adsorption or MIP, which only measure accessible pores within a limited size range, SANS method has been proved to be a powerful tool to effectively characterize the pores in a wider size range, including both the accessible and inaccessible pore space [22]. SANS method does not rely on the interaction of pore space with a fluid (e.g., liquid mercury for MIP or nitrogen for low pressure gas adsorption method) as a probe for porosity quantification. In addition, SANS technique is fast, and does not require complex sample preparation; however, a lack of access to neutron scattering facilities for SANS experiments is a disadvantage.
In this study, SANS technique was applied on four Longmaxi shale samples (JY-01 to -04) that represent overmature gasproducing shale reservoir (2.4–4.2% Ro [46–49]) with a range of different lithology. These four representative samples with different lithofacies were suitable to illustrate the nature and complexity of pore structure of Longmaxi shale. The major objective of this work is to determine the pore structure characteristics (e.g., pore size distribution, surface area and total porosity, the fraction of closed pores) over the size range 5–500 nm. In addition, the results of the pore structure parameters are also compared to other conventional methods, which have been reported in previous works [5,20]. This work can be beneficial to understand the nature of pore structure, gas storage and transport mechanisms and gas production behavior, and the findings in this study are also broadly applicable to other fine-grained and tight rocks.

sections.heading: 2.1. Geological setting and samples
sections.text:
Longmaxi shale, also called as ‘‘hot shale” in North Africa and Arabia [50], is a late Silurian-age marine shelf deposit in Sichuan Basin, ranging in thickness from several meters in the west region to about 300 m (984.3 ft) to the southeast [20,51]. Overall, Longmaxi Formation is a set of black organic-rich shale (total organic carbon contents vary from 0.46% to 6.79%, with an average of 2.62% [52]), composed of carbonaceous shale, argillaceous siltstone and siliceous shale with low permeability (mainly at 1.1 10 6– 1 10 4 lm2 with an average of 1.6 10 4 lm2 [52,53]). It is observed that the black Longmaxi shale is also rich in fossils, e.g., radiolarian, calthrop and graptolite, indicating a low-energy and anoxic sedimentary environment [33,47,51,54]. Currently, over 200 gas-producing wells are drilled in southeastern margin of Sichuan Basin by Sinopec (China), with commercially viable levels using horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing technologies, which connect the matrix pores through a complex fracture-pore network. However, gas production from this black shale is still challenging with a rapid decline (about 60%) of production behavior in the first year, and this may be related to the limited understanding of nano-scale pore structure of Longmaxi shale matrix [55].
In this study, four shale samples at different depth were taken from Longmaxi Formation in Well Jiaoye #1 (drilled by China Petrochemical Corporation [Sinopec Group] in November 2012),
which is also the first shale gas well of commercial exploitation in China [35]. Table 1 exhibits the detail information about these samples, including burial depth, lithology, total organic carbon (TOC) content, and thermal maturity. All the Longmaxi shale samples present in this study are overmature as indicated by the equivalent vitrinite reflectance values of 2.2–3.35% (within dry gas generation window). These shale samples are very rich in organic matter, varying from 1.53 wt.% to 4.97 wt.% with an average of 3.09 wt.%. Using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (X’Pert PRO MPD from Panalytical Company), the mineralogical compositions of shale samples were determined at a working voltage of 40 kV and current of 40 mA. The mineral compositions (including TOC) in terms of weight (wt.%) are given in Table 2 and these values are converted to volume (vol.%) percent using the shale matrix density for each mineral (shown in Table 2). Accounting for about 70% or more of these shale samples, quartz and clay are the dominant minerals. There is an obviously inverse relationship between quartz and clay content, which is generally similar with those observed in Devonian gas shale in Horn River Basin from Canada [56,57]. According to the organic mudstone lithofacies [58], JY-01 and JY-02 are classified as argillaceous/siliceous mudstone, while JY-03 and JY-04 are clay-rich siliceous mudstone. These four samples were selected specifically to have an increasing TOC content and similar thermal maturity values, thus the effect of thermal maturity can be eliminated while the variation of pore structure with different TOC contents and mineral compositions is observed.

sections.heading: 2.2. SANS experiment
sections.text:
Prior to the test, samples were first cut to about 0.5 cm thick with a trim saw in air parallel to bedding surface; in order to minimize multiple scattering, the samples were polished to their final thickness of 0.7 mm (about 1 cm width and 1 cm length). Polished samples were dried in a vacuum oven at 60 C for 24 h to remove volatile substances and free water. SANS experiments were conducted on the General Purpose SANS instrument at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) in Tennessee, using neutron wavelengths of 4.72 Å and 12 Å (Dk/k 0.15). In a SANS experiment, with its schematic shown in Melnichenko et al. [42], the neutron beam is directed at the sample, and scattered elastically due to the interaction with nuclei of atoms. Three sample-to-detector distances (18.5 m, 10 m and 1 m) were used to cover an absolute value of scattering vector (Q) range of 1 10 3–0.5 Å 1. SANS experiments were conducted at ambient conditions, and the samples were confined in standard demountable cells with titanium body and quartz windows.
Generally, the neutron scattering contrast for different shale solid matrix is very small compared to the contrast between the
shale matrix (including TOC) and pore space. Thus, in this study, shale sample is regarded as a two-phase (shale solid matrix/pore space) scattering systems, and the data can generally be interpreted accurately using a two-phase approximation. In addition, only the coherent scattering cross section contains information about structure of the samples, whereas the incoherent cross section provides no information on interference effects and can form an isotropic background. Therefore, the raw SANS data was corrected for instrument backgrounds, as well as detection efficiency, and converted to absolute units using pre-calibrated secondary standards [22,59].

sections.heading: 3. Theoretical background of SANS method
sections.text:
During the past decades, it is reported that SANS technique has many applications to petroleum geology, e.g., investigate the microstructure of complex porous rocks, determine the onset of hydrocarbon generation and migration in source rock, and evaluate the gas sorption capacity of coal and shales [27,28,41,42,45,59,60]. Homogeneous porous medium, such as some artificial materials, can be perceived as a nearly homogeneous mass for a random two-phase (e.g., pore space/solid matrix) system [29]. Thus this kind of homogeneous medium is comprised of two different phases with different values of scattering length density (SLD). Specifically, the porous medium consists of a solid matrix with a constant SLD (phase 1) and pores that are random in pore geometry (phase 2), and a sharp interface exist between the two phases. It is fairly straightforward to calculate the SLD of one component skeletons, whereas situation often becomes complicated for many geological samples (e.g., shale is heterogeneous in mineral composition) as they are comprised of multiple components, such as minerals and TOC. As for geological samples, the neutron scattering length density qn for each component mineral can be calculated using the following formula [45]:

sections.text:
The specific surface area of a fractal surface, whether selfsimilar or self-affine, is strongly related to the size of the probe used. For certain probe size r, the specific surface area can be calculated from the pore size distribution as the sum of surface areas of all pores, of radius larger than r, divided by the sample volume [63],

sections.heading: 3.3. Fractal dimension
sections.text: When a object or quantity displays a self-similarity under scale transformations, it is considered to be fractal in the field of fractal geometry. Fractal dimension, including mass fractal, surface fractal and pore fractal, is widely used to evaluate the structure of random system. In the more general case of fractal morphologies, the scattering intensity for a fractal object or quantity follows a power law with scattering vector dRdX ðQÞ Q D in the large Q-range. Using SANS techniques, the exponent D can differentiate between fractal and non-fractal pores. Specifically, when the values of exponent D range from 3 to 4, it belongs to surface fractal; while exponent D < 3 corresponds to mass fractal (i.e., aggregates) and D > 4 indicates nonfractal diffuse interfaces [45].

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1a shows the plot of SANS absolute scattering cross section (I(Q)) versus the scattering vector (Q) for four Longmaxi samples.
Scattering intensity exhibits clear negative relationship with Q values, but remain relatively flat in large Q range (Fig. 1a). In this study, the scattering intensity at Q value of 0.5 Å 1 is referred as the ‘‘flat” background (bkgd) [27], and their estimated values are also shown in Fig. 1a. JY-04 has the highest ‘‘flat” background value and the smallest background value is observed for JY-01. It is reported that this scattering ‘‘flat” background is most likely caused by the combined effect of the incoherent scattering of hydrogen nuclei present in the organic matter and formation water present in the shale, and the microscopic pore system present in the shale matrix [27,43]. The scattering profile, shown in Fig. 1a, exhibits a linear regime in a log-log scale with a scattering vector (Q) less than 0.1 Å 1, suggesting that the reliable data were limited to this Q region. The ‘‘flat” region (0.1 Å 1 6 Q 6 0.5 Å 1) would provide incorrect information about the geometry of the nanopores and were therefore excluded from further analysis in this study. Additionally, in order to remove the effect of ‘‘flat” background, the background values have been subtracted from the scattering intensity for each sample (Fig. 1b).
Using Eqs. (1) and (2) and the data from Table 3, the average SLD value for each Longmaxi shale was calculated as a sum of SLDs of all the mineral composition (including TOC) weighted by their volume fraction and the results are present in Table 1, varying from 3.58 for JY-02 to 3.81 in JY-04. Based on PRINSAS software [63], the background-subtracted SANS data were analyzed using PDSP model, assuming a three-dimensional pore space. The PDSP model analysis was repeated and the quality of fit is excellent (Fig. 1b). The Q-region of the power-law scattering, shown in Fig. 1b, extends seven orders of magnitude of scattering cross section

As for spherical pores that are randomly distributed and fractal in pore size distribution, there is a approximate relationship between scattering vector (Q) and pore radius (r): r 2.5/Q [65]. Therefore, the scattering data in this study can probe a theoretical pore diameter range of about 5–500 nm, covering the pores from microscopic to nearly micrometer scale.
According to the equations for fractal dimension determination, the slopes of the four samples in the log-log plot (Fig. 1b) exhibit straight-line fits in the region of 10 3 Å 1 6 Q 6 10 1 Å 1, ranging from 2.801 for JY-03 to 2.999 in JY-01 (Table 1). The slopes shown in the log-log plot reflects the scale invariance or fractal behavior of the distributions of scattering objects. According to the equation mentioned in fractal dimension section, these exponent Ds are smaller than 3, suggestive of the mass fractal character in Longmaxi shales. In the previous study [5], the fractal dimensions of Longmaxi shales are also calculated from low pressure N2 adsorption using Frenkel-Halsey-Hill model. Low pressure N2 adsorption indicates Longmaxi shale are surface fractal with fractal dimensions between 2.737 and 2.823. It seems that there is an inconsistency between SANS data and low pressure N2 adsorption. However, it is not the case. Low pressure N2 adsorption data focuses on the connected pores and the N2 molecule is adsorbed onto the walls of these pores. only the actually measured scattering intensity in the range of 10 3 Å 1 6 Q 6 10 1 Å 1, and the scattering intensity at low and high Q-ranges is not involved. Fig. 3(a) shows that all the shale samples are characterized by power-law-like size distribution, and are generally consistent with pore size distribution from low pressure N2 adsorption [20]. Sample JY-01 is obviously different with others, and two obvious peaks at around 30 Å and 60 Å are observed. This different pore size distribution shapes for JY-01, may be related to the relative low TOC content (1.53 wt.%), and the numbers of nano-pores related with organic matter pores is relatively smaller than other samples. This speculation is generally consistent with the SEM images in previous studies [5]. The largest specific surface area based on PDSP model is observed in JY-04 (1.45 105 cm 1), followed by JY-03, and JY-01 has the smallest value of 2.13 104 cm 1 (Table 1, Fig. 3b and c). In contrast, the values of PDSP surface area are slighter larger than Porod specific surface areas, but smaller than the BET specific surface area. Even though some pore spaces are not accessible to N2 adsorption, a significant amount of pores with diameter <5 nm exist in Longmaxi shales. Regardless of the absolute values, the variation trend of the calculated specific surface area between these four shale samples is quite consistent with previous studies that there is an obvious positive relationship between the specific surface area and the TOC content (Table 1).
Total porosity of each sample was determined using the Porod invariant (Eq. (5)) and PDSP model (Eq. (6)), and the results are present in Table 1, as well as the MIP porosity data [20]. It is noted that
the porosity values are slightly different between these methods, and all the Porod porosities are smaller than PDSP values, which is most likely caused by the different principles in calculation. In contrast, all the MIP porosity values in the pore size range of 5– 500 nm are comparable to Porod porosity results, but lower than PDSP values. This may be related to the fact that SANS method provides information on total pore space (including closed and open pores), whereas MIP only probe the pore space accessible to mercury.
The fraction of closed pore (%) can be defined as: Uclosed pores = (USANS UMIP)/USANS, where USANS is the porosity calculated from SANS technique based on PDSP or Porod model, %; UMIP represents the porosity obtained from MIP method, %. According to this equation, the fractions of closed pore for these four Longmaxi shales are calculated and given in Table 1. It is evident the fraction of closed pores increase with the depth and reach the maximum at the JY04, suggesting that a significant volume of pore space are closed and this is generally consistent with reported FE-SEM studies [5]. At the bottom of Longmaxi shales, the large volume of irregular organic matter are heterogeneously distributed, resulting in the development of very complicated pore network, as well as the increasing fraction of closed pores.
Regardless of methods or models for porosity determination, the total porosities shown in Table 1 are different for each sample. Previous studies have revealed that porosity variation in shale has a strong relationship with the generation and expulsion of hydrocarbon at increasing thermal maturity [4,13,66]. The thermal

The porosity values increase with the depth, which may be related with the different TOC content and mineral compositions. Previous study from SEM images on Longmaxi shale has also indicated that, with the increasing of TOC content, the organic matter pores are well developed at the bottom of Longmaxi shale, as well as some intra- and interparticle pores within and among the clay minerals [5].
Fig. 4 shows the scattering intensity versus sample depth at four different Q values (2 10 3, 5 10 3, 1 10 2 and 8 10 2 Å 1) and their curve shapes are similar. Overall, with the increasing of depth and Q values from 2 10 3 Å 1 to 8 10 2 Å 1, the scattering intensity decrease over five magnitudes from 10,000 cm 1 to <1 cm 1, which may reflect the differences in the certain scale structure of scatters at various burial depths. For a certain Q value, with the increasing depth, the scattering intensity values initially increase slowly from JY-01 to JY-02, and then increase rapidly from JY-02 to JY-04, suggesting the maximum porosity value for JY-04 and the minimum in JY-01. By monitoring the properties (porosity and compressibility) of rock matrix, previous studies have used similar plots to determine the depth of onset of hydrocarbon generation, expulsion and oil-to-gas cracking on immature or mature hydrocarbon source rock [65]. However, due to the limited samples and the fact that Longmaxi shales are in overmature stage within dry gas generation window, the exact onset depth of hydrocarbon generation and expulsion cannot be determined in this study, which will be studied in the future work.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: A preliminary application of SANS technique has been conducted on organic-rich overmature Longmaxi shales, and results show that SANS technique is valuable to study nano-scale pore space frommicroscopic to nearly micrometer scale. Over the entire Q-range, the absolute scattering intensities for the sample with higher TOC content are greater. Slope values in the log-log plot reflects the scale invariance or fractal behavior of the distributions of scattering objects, and suggest the mass fractal character in Longmaxi shales. Pore structure parameters (surface area, pore size distribution and porosity) are calculated using PDSP and Porod methods, and both of them are larger than the corresponding MIP results. This may be related to the fact that SANS method provides information on total pore space (including closed and open pores), whereas MIP only probe the pore space accessible to mercury. With an increase of depth and Q values, the scattering intensity show quite opposite variation trend, suggesting differences in the certain scale structure of scatters at various burial depths. The fractions of closed pore also increase with depth, which is related with the TOC content and mineral composition and is partially developed during the development of very complicated pore network.

metadata.abstractText: Longmaxi Formation is the leading target play of shale gas development in Sichuan Basin (China) with a large amount of natural gas produced from this organic-rich overmature shale since 2014. In order to investigate the nano-scale pore system, small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) technique was applied on four Longmaxi shale samples (JY-01 to -04) with a range of different lithology. The scattering length density (SLD) for each sample is calculated as a volume average using the chemical composition of different mineral components, with values from 3.58 10 10 cm 2 in JY-02 to 3.81 10 10 cm 2 in JY-04. Scattering results and analyses reveal Longmaxi shales are mass fractal with an exponent D less than 3. Pore size distribution, specific surface area and porosity are calculated using Porod invariant method and Polydisperse spherical pore (PDSP) model, and are comparable to mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) results, suggesting SANS is valuable to study nano-scale pore space from microscopic to nearly micrometer scale. In addition, with the increasing depth and the scattering vector (Q) values, the scattering intensity decrease over five orders of magnitude, reflecting the differences in the certain scale structure of scatters at various burial depths of Longmaxi shale. For a certain Q value, with an increasing depth, the scattering intensity values initially increase slowly first, and then increase rapidly.
